comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Read All About It!, including an engraving of this photo, AT&CJ 12/2/1876 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70588890. And another engraving from further back - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63333606

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: From the first link - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70588890 - " ... At 6 a.m. [on Saturday 5/2/1876] the boats made ready, from the Hibernia, which was anchored one-third of a mile off. A great length of cable rope was stretched from the ship to the main land, 100 yards east of the place where the cable was to be landed. The life-boat, with the first portion of the cable on board followed, and the cable looped from seven other boats, was carried to the shore. When sufficiently far to the east, the main boat swerved back, and by this means abundance of slack cable was secured to reach into the operating room. The life boat, with the cable, was manned by a strong crew, who enlivened the proceedings by chanting sea-songs. The attendance of spectators was not numerous. Among those present were noticed the officers, engineers, and electricians of the ship, Mr. Dickenson (Learmonth, Dickinson, and Co., the agents of tho cabie vessels), Mr. John Rae, Mr. E. C. Cracknell, Mr. F. W. Hill, Mr. Phillip B. Walker, Mr. Wilson, Mr. Dalgarno, Mr. Wise, Mr. W. Hill, Mr. Peck, Mr. O'Sullivan, Captain McDermott, and Mr. Skarrat. When the first boat was brought with a heavy rope attached to the cable, the whole of the spectators cheerfully rendered assistance to the officers and crew, and dragged the life-boat in. At 7.30 a.m., the cable end was landed, and in twenty minutes afterwards connection was established. In two minutes after connection a remarkable feat was accomplished. As before explained, the cable is laid on the Hibernia in three large tanks, each containing over four hundred miles of wire. Each tank is connected, and a message was received at the station from the ship saying, "All right," or "O. K," the message having traversed the whole length of the wire which, if stretched, would reach to New Zealand. This piece of intelligence was highly satisfactory. In about an hour afterwards (ten minutes past 9 a.m.) the Hibernia began to steam slowly away, accompanied for a short distance by the Ajax and Mystery, and at 9.30 she passed through the Heads on her way to New Zealand, paying out the line without the slightest hitch. Shortly afterwards the Edinburgh started. Several other tests were taken, and proved that communication was perfect, when the Hibernia got out to sea. In addition to the information already furnished, it will be interesting to know that the total length of the line will be about 1370 nautical miles. ... .... "

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] So nice to make John Rae's acquaintance once again! See also State Library of NSW dry plate (copy) negatives (February 1876): Laying of the Pacific Ocean cable, La Perouse, Botany Bay [Digital order no. d1_05253] Electric telegraph officers' camp: laying the cable, Botany Bay [Digital order no. d1_05257] Electric telegraph officers' camp: laying the cable, Botany Bay [Digital order no. d1_05258]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Reproduced in Our Yesterdays: Australian Life Since 1853 in Photographs by Irma & Cyril Pearl, Angus & Robertson, London, 1954, p. 57; and Australia: Image of a Nation 1850-1950 by David Moore & Rodney Hall, William Collins Pty Ltd, Sydney, 1983, pp. 150-151 [double-page spread]. They both cite the NSW Government Printing Office as the creator - which means the original negative might be somewhere at NSW State Records. It could in fact be a Public Works Department photograph (whose negatives were transferred to the GPO in 1929). Rae could be the photographer (the PWD photographer before 1883 is still unknown), or at least he could have been responsible for ensuring the occasion was photographed, in his role as Under-secretary of Public Works. Interesting to note that both books use the quote from the newspaper extract above about the sailors "who enlivened the proceedings by chanting sea-songs" in their descriptive captions.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: According to a handwritten note on the back of one of the Mitchell Library's copies of this photograph (they have several), the paddle steamer is the New Zealand built ROYAL ALFRED (1873) [Call Number SPF / 1470]. It certainly looks like the ROYAL ALFRED - see: "Royal Alfred" at wharf Circular Quay [Digital order no. d1_20453]. However, the newspaper articles only mention the presence of the tug steamer MYSTERY and the Government steamer AJAX under instruction "to render assistance in landing the shore end of the cable if necessary." But it's not the AJAX: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/3324488944/]The tug "Ajax" and the ship "Highlander", Newcastle, NSW, 28 October 1897 from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/] Cultural Collections

comment.author: 32162360@N00
32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I was also thinking that John Rae might well be the photographer (especially with the provenance), or at least have had the insight to record the occasion.  The fellow noted in the photo is just my educated guess,  and he is wearing far too smart white clothes to do anything practical !

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33147718@N05] - Sorry, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] and I get excited when John Rae is mentioned, originally because of that photo from his house. Apart from being a mover and shaker in NSW, he was also an artist and photographer; photos possibly by him keep turning up. Another example - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5763060299/

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  We knew you guys would like this one! Thanks for all the info, our records have been updated. BC its lovely to see the image used as an engraving in AT&CJ and Pelle we'll be sure to tag you in if any John Rae material comes up ;)
